something i'd like to point out- while latex or nitrile gloves won't last long against concentrated or fuming nitric acid, good lab practice dictates that if you even think you might have any spill on your gloves, you must immediately remove and replace them. as such, the gloves aren't so much resisting indefinitely, but rather just buying you a few extra seconds (much longer than it takes to remove the gloves).

The use of ammonium nitrate is perfectly acceptable in this process.  As a matter of fact, I consistently have higher yields using the ammonium salt than when using sodium or potassium nitrate.  Ammonia is NOT a byproduct of the reaction and, contrary to what the gentleman states in the video, no neutralization of the product takes place.  If this were to happen, you would end up with ammonium nitrate, your starting reactant, which represents the reverse reaction pathway.  Because product (nitric acid) is constantly being distilled off, the reaction is driven only in the forward direction, all the way to completion.  The only products are WFNA, ammonium hydrogen sulfate and, initially, a small amount of NO2 gas.  

Starting with pure, uncoated ammonium nitrate that has been pulverized in a coffee grinder will minimize the amount of oxides of nitrogen produced.  It will be much easier to clean out the cake of ammonium bisulfate in the reaction flask if you begin with a slight molar excess of sulfuric acid.  You must wait until the flask is completely cooled before attempting to clean your glassware as concentrated sulfuric acid reacts violently with water.  I usually add ice chips initially to keep the spatter to a minimum.

A couple more tips:  This procedure produces pure nitric acid of 100% concentration, otherwise known as white fuming nitric acid (WFNA).  It is not unusual for the final product to contain a small amount of dissolved oxides of nitrogen, mostly nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and its dimer dinitrogen tetroxide (N2O4) in equilibrium.  This product is called red fuming nitric acid (RFNA).  Depending on the reaction that you intend to use the acid for, these dissolved gases may or may not be desirable.  To rid the product of oxides of nitrogen, you can bubble very dry air or nitrogen through it.  Another easy way to do this is to add urea a pinch at a time until it no longer fizzes when added.  This does not contaminate the acid as the reaction between NO2 and urea produces only gaseous products (CO2 and N2).  Unless you intend to use the nitric acid immediately, you must store it in tightly sealed amber bottles, preferably in the freezer.  It is unstable to both light and heat, decomposing into NO2 and H2O over time.
